												Total Annihilation is the defining game of the RTS genre. Looking back to the late 90s and the technology available then, this game was amazingly advanced and did many things that weren't at all common then. Many common RTS elements that are expected in a game released today can be seen in their youth in TA. The order queuing system, the streaming resource and building systems, the diversity of units and asymmetrical factions are all key features that were later used in practically every RTS since. You can clearly see the foundation of Supreme Commander especially. There are aspects of TA that still haven’t been matched, such as the unit diversity: Air, Land, Sea, Seaplane, Hovercraft, Amphibious.Like artillery? How about the Intimidator, which can fire halfway across the map? Too slow? Build the Buzzsaw: a giant rotary cannon made up of Intimidators that fires as fast as a machine gun and will drain your energy economy in seconds. Yes, it IS the most entertaining gun ever!The music of TA is the best orchestral soundtrack ever made for a game. I still sometimes listen to the "battle" tracks in my car. I turn the music off in every other game I’ve played and listen to “real” music instead (I remember listening to Spice Girls on a CD while playing), but TA got to keep its soundtrack.I think a large part of what made TA such a fun and long lasting experience was the modding community. I remember spending as much time finding, downloading (V.90 modem, yo), and figuring out conflicts between mods as playing the game, but those mods extended the diversity and playability of the game so extensively that there are still active players AND active modders for TA. You don’t see that with too many 19 year-old games.The chief contender for the RTS throne was Starcraft, which was released right around the same time as TA, and went on to define the "twitch" RTS subgenre. Coming from Warcraft 2, I remember buying both games, and being rather disappointed in Starcraft, since it seemed to me to be "Warcraft in space". TA was something entirely new and captured that certain something that makes it a gaming classic... and I've probably spent more time in this game than any other, ever.

												Word of Warning it is a nostalgic game.A true RTS Game that could be said to have out lasted Starcraft Brood War and inspired the next generation of Real Time Stratergy games, Remember fondly playing this game as a kid and back in the day it was perhaps one of the first community driven games that boasted thousands of mods and total conversions from Star Wars to the Modern World this game was much like the Skyrim of the 90's with an seemingly endless supply of units, mods, and creativity on the part of the community.Unsurprisingly this hasn't changed, Total Annihilation still retains a small but solid community of players ranging from Casuals to Professionals all it covers all the basis for a RTS game but not without it's issues.The base game is known to suffer from pathfinding issues, you'll frequently find that without the use of mods or modified scripts the AI will struggle considerably and will at times do stupid things that might ruin the experiance of players looking for a challenge, if that's you then I'd recommend either playing with friends or joining one of the many communities out their!Or look into getting one of the many mods the game supports, most if not all improve the AI come to ruthless degrees where you'll hard pressed to both micro and marco manage an entire force of soulless machines. The best way I can descrbe it would be to think of Skyrim without mods, then think of Skyrim with mods that's effectively TA in a nuthshell.Options:+ The developers certainly had longevity in mind, you can adjust the resolution up to 1920 x 1080.+ Provides all the options you might expect from a game of this age, perhaps abit more.- On/Off only, you can't find a middle ground without adjusting the files directly.Gameplay+ A map for everybody! - every map has something for everybody the metal maps provide infinite resources and lead to a fast-paced style game. In contrast low metal maps have you fighting over resources while slowly pushing your way into the enemy base. Maps on distant moons have you transporting units by air over impassable chasms or bombing your opponent into the dust.+ Play how you want - Many RTS games have a 'defined' stratergy TA has no such definition, you will encounter players who love the good old peepee rush or those whose sole purpose is to watch you squirm as they destroy your outlying extractors. You'll encounter the turtles naturally but the game provides you with all the nessesary tools to enact your stratergy and descimate others.- AI Pathfinding - As mentioned the pathfinding is horrible and will almost certainly require fixing especially if you want to play Skirmish thankfully their are mods and simple scripts to fix this.- Performance - Most modern day PC's won't have a problem until like Skyrim you hit a point where your computer begins to chug along. This tends to arise from heavily modded games especially when you start to up the unit cap from 200 to 1000+Community:+ Still going strong not much else to say here besides the fact you have over 10 years of mods to discover some of which have been developed over so many years.

												It looks like just a bunch of robots killing each other to most people, but Total Annihilation is one of the deepest darkest stories ever told. It's the only accurate game I've ever seen about our future, where humans are all dead and the arm clones fight the core planetary mind for control of the universe.  They don't even care about being alive or anything, they just want to annihilate the other side so so much. It also has a great soundtrack written by Jeremy Seole, who wrote a lot of the music in Secret of Evermore.  The first time I saw Total Annihilation, I was in Circuit City and I saw this cool looking guy getting bombed by 50 fast moving fighters and planes and he couldn't stop the computer from killing him and he eventually lost his commander and then his last towers and the map went grey.  It was like 1997 or something and he must have been horrible at the game and I don't think either of us bought anything from circuit city that day, but to see that cool guy get annihilated by an endless wave of planes was shocking to me.  He said "damn it" or something like that and then looked at his watch and said "oh no" and then he ran away, I guess he had to go somewhere and was late.  I saw it as a great challenge to become as good as he was some day, and I still feel like I'm not, but objectively I must have met that challenge because I have won wars against 10 computer players with population limits in the thousands.  If I could go back in time, I would go back there, ask him if i could help, and save his base.

												My favorite game as a child, i quickly snapped up the DRM Free edition availible through GOG.com. Now OTA is here on Steam in all its glory! It wasnt Starcraft or Command & Conquer that set the bar for late 90s rts games. OTA is the undisputed and most refferenced old-school RTS that to this day inspires the finer qualities in the EPIC War genre we crave.Its important to note *though steam failed to mention it in the product details* This edition includes all DLC along with the main game (Original Total Annihilation, Core contengency Expansion, All of the Battle Tactics Expansions, Bonus Maps, Bonus Official Cavedog Units, Patch 3.1 known as the "No CD Patch" Patch 3.1 also is tweaked with the expanded unit cap which can be modified in the system files to a maximum of 5000 units per player in a 10 player battle. updated and fully supported multiplayer hosting for matches complete with thier own communities... The Added bennefit of the Steam Edition is access to the steam community for multiplayer compatibility. by comparison it is identical to the GOG edition with exception that the steam version has better compatibility with modern windows OS. Both copies work seamlessly with Wine if you use Linux or Mac. I reccomend the Steam edition for ease of gaming with friends. but the GOG.com version is DRM Free meaning you can buy one copy and then gift as many as you want to your friends per thier TOS agreement.-----Some useful details about the game not mentioned in the description-----Minor Bug: Due to this being a rather ancient game... there is an issue with the screen rendering of the game for flat screens which will cause a periodic flicker. Alt Tab didnt exist back then either so you should press the Windows key to minimise your game if you wish to chat with your steam buddies outside of the game. This however has an issue where the the screen will tweak out into odd colors... just minimize and maximize a couple times and the emulator steam uses to run the game will adjust and fix the issue pretty reliably. This is caused by the change in formatting for video displays after the flat screen transition.Some Extra Stuff:by default the multiplayer loby should have this enabled due to game additions added for both the GOG.com & Steam versions of the game. If you accidently shrink your lobby down or it appears as the old default of maximum of 4 players for skirmish and multi, simply press the 8 key on your keyboard followed by the roman numeral key from 2 to 10 indicating the max player matches. so 2 would be "8 ii" while 10 would be "8 x".to enter a "console code" while playing multiplayer or skirmish game modes simply press Enter and type + followed by the command. (The older versions of the game allowed some console commands to work in single player but the 3.1 patch made many commands nonfunctional or were removed all together. Many of these commands are now only availible within the develloper mode which you will need to download from TAUniverse & other fansites. It is possible to reinable them by editing the configuration files but the engine will not allow you to play multiplayer with other clients that have different files then you.)some useful console commands are +gamma, +contour, & +showranges. These dont really break gameplay and fully function in all gamemodes, so enabling cheats to use these functions is ok if you agree with your gamemates that they can be used.+gamma lets you adjust the brightness of the screen "+gamma 8.5" was default for the old tube monitors... you can play around with this if you have lighting issues. +contour is useful for seeing the 3D terrain elivations and is highly useful as nobody back then had a concept of strategic zoom like what was introduced by Supreme Commander. +contour 5 is best i think as it still lets you view the pretty terrain features while letting you put that factory on the perfect spot easier. type +contour with no number to remove the elivation overlay. if you put a value in decimal that is less then one you will need to place a zero before the decimal for it to register... note this can cause framerate loss or artificial slowdown of the game for really minor details. in case of a game crash you will need to reinstall yourgame if you input values lower then 0.045.+showranges indicates the ranges of the various weapons on mobile units. it doesnt work on fixed fortifications which was fixed when they included the same feature in Supreme Commander. By default all units have an explosion range where they will harm other units within that range... and most units have 1 - 2 weapon ranges which might be off screen if its a long ranged weapon. some specdial units will by default have other indicators depending on functionality such as a cloak or stealth/jammer field that should be enabled by default.a neat feature on the main menu is to type "dxdeath" which will enable or disable a Cavedog logo in the lower middle of the menuscreen. if you click that... in the old days it would allow you to view the credit screen... also while enabled it would allow you to manually pick missions rather then unlocking missions as you played.--another 2 codes that are neat but may become annoying for various reasons are +sing & +dither.+sing replaces the vehical sounds of units with a guy singing some nonsensical toon.+dither changes the gray scale of the out of view zones in the game to a "dithered" or bug-screen colored view. it looked great on the old analog tube monitors but causes major flickering issues on modern digital flatscreens. DO NOT USE THIS IF YOU HAVE EPILEPSY or are at risk for seizures or taking medications with this risk (regular gameplay on flatscreens however is completely safe)... there is no warning for this feature as this game predates those videogame warnings by like 10 years.

												My parents got us a used PC with a Pentium I in 1997, which was nothing to scoff at in Eastern Europe at that time. The odds of the machine arriving with Total Annihilation on it's hard drive however seem incredible to me in hindsight. Of course initially, we, a 7-, 4- and 3-year-old didn't have much of a clue what we were doing playing this game, but I reckon by the time I was 10 or so I started getting better, reaching higher campaign missions. Never had the skill to complete the game back then though and I spent most of the time nuking the AI player on a random map with infinite metal, which was great fun in itself.Shortly before writing this review, I didn't know TA won Game of the Year in 1997, or even that it was made in 1997, but replaying this classic really made me realize why I was less impressed than my peers with later titles like Age of Empires 2 or Command & Conquer. TA had simply done so much better before them and I knew of it. I kid you not, Total Annihilation would be a strong title if it was released today. The mechanics of destruction feel so satisfying. Even the graphics don't look too bad. Most of today's titles cannot match it's diversity of units. TA had a pseudo-3D world where hills obstruct artillery fire, unit task queues and radar almost 20 years ago and I haven't even seen a similar veteran unit mechanic since. Even the story (I mean how cool is a Jupiter Brain?) is good and the soundtrack great. 7-year-old me in 1997 would have massively overestimated what a 2016 RTS title should look like based on this game, but I also get that if RTS-s would have progressed from TA to better as fast as things move in today's world, they would have become too complicated for most of the population by 1999 and everyone would have jumped ship for something simpler like Starcraft anyway.So yeah, it's highly debatable if any RTS has surpassed Cavedog's 1997 masterpiece, which works on a Pentium I, to this day.

												TL;DR: Buy this. It's worth it.Total Annihilation.Damn.This game was my childhood. I remember sitting on my Dad's lap and we'd build up our army together and then nuke the CORE to pieces. Those were the days.Total Annihilation is a Real-Time Strategy game. You start off with one 'Unit', your Commander, and slowly build up your army of planes, vehicles, mechs, boats, hovercraft, etc. For a game that is 20 years old this year this is STILL in my opinion the greatest RTS game of all time. This is the type of game that despite the graphics being massively outdated, and only 1.1GB big (not even that), it's still feels full of content. The maps are HUGE and there's lots of variety. The Units all have their own jobs and characteristics. There's a campaign too, and also, if you can figure out how to get it to work, a multiplayer. At the time of writing this review it only says I have 2.1 hours on record, but to be truthful I probably have hundereds outside of Steam. 												This game is quite possibly the single greatest video game ever made. When it was released in 1997, Total Annihilation was so far ahead of its time that in some respects it has never been duplicated since.At the time I write this review there is no Steamworks multiplayer or Workshop mod support. But if these things are implemented, I have no doubts whatsoever that we will see a huge resurgence of Total Annihilation. There are already tens of thousands of third-party units, many mega-mods of hundreds of units, total conversions for everything from Star Wars to WWII to Gundam, to entirely new games built on TA as a basis. The amount of strategic depth flowing from fairly simple rules of collecting metal from metal spots and using it to construct various types of units, using a continous economy, physics-based battles, and a serious need for planning and tactics rather than unit counter relationships, make Total Annihilation a much deeper and more interesting strategy game than most of its contemporary cousins, including Starcraft and Age of Empires.Real time strategy games have been starved for ideas for many years now, with the most successful ones being sequels and spiritual successors to genuinely innovative strategy games from the '90s. Alongside Starcraft, Total Annihilation is one of the great progenitors of the modern era of strategy games, and in many respects it has never been equaled.

												Critical part of gaming history, and a must-have addition to anyone looking to look at gaming's history. This is one of the major three archetypes of RTS, those being C&C, TA, and SC in terms of gameplay semblance. Games usually follow one of these three determinite paths, as these are archetypes, so you should probably look at those if you're intrested in RTS games and want to make one too.Total Annihilation is the creation of Chris Taylor, an industry veteran and, interestingly enough, Toy maker. You can see why he would eventually partner with THQ or TOY HEADQUARTERS.As a toymaker, naturally, chris taylor took this same idea to game creation, and eventually with his team, Cavedog created Total Annihilation. Not satisfied with the SC and C&C, the developers went "Wait a second, no. this is wrong. We need MORE UNITS." And so it was. Whilst C&C never traditionally had a unit cap, it was not specifically made for this, where as TA was specifically constructed with an emphasis on massive armies.The story involves you, as THE LAST COMMANDER OF YOUR FACTION, either arm or core, to quite simply, annihilate the other faction. This war began over the concept of patterning that, at mass civilian request, made mandatory for citizen protection, as their conciousness was saved and preserved on massive databanks and transfered to machine. This is what became CORE CONCIOUSNESS, and then later CORE. Both of their names hold a lot of semblance. ARM is not machines, rather, mass numbers of cloned individuals that detested the move to machines. ARM possesses it's central HQ in an ARM of the galaxy, where CORE is, well, the core. At this point, there are endless ruined worlds by this war's wake. Now all that's left is the other faction, and the only acceptable outcome for the other is...TOTAL               ANNIHILATION.

												This game simply oozes 90's charm, from gameplay to experiencing the limitations.A lot of people who are not long time RTS fans will probably get turned off by this game, just from looking at it.I do, however, encourage people to play this game.This game is still to this day years, decades even, ahead of it's time.From the notion of destroyed unit husks blocking unit movement, to the sheer scale of how powerful simple units can be.And for once in an RTS I actually feel like an Experimental unit, is Experimental.The Krogoth is an amazing unit that, while yes, does take a long time to build, can dish out serious firepower, however unlike Experimental units of today it is not Nigh-on invincible, and can die reletively easily, but can quickly pave the way for an army.The one big downside to the Krogoth is that only the CORE can build it, so if you're the ARM, you might want to build up your artillery.Although you'll probably never reach the point of actually building the Krogoth since it does take a considerable amount of time to build.The game also has a booming soundtrack, composed by the one and only Jeremy Soule, who also composed the music for Elder Scrolls, Guild Wars and other hit/Cult Classic titles.Very few composers such as Soule actually still compose today.Frank Klepaki is one such artist, alough his Command and Conquer work, will probably still be his best.The only game that I could recommend to ever coming close to TA, is probably Dark Reign, and even that doesn't come anywhere near the level this game produced.Pros:-The game is quite fluid, and offers quite a great deal of control over your units.-The future setting works in its favor instead of against it (Even to this day).-The music is masterfully crafted to suit the game's tone and ambition.-The art is quite unique and no 2 units look the same.-One of the very few RTS of its time to use more than 1 resource and be balanced-Maps are expertly crafted so that no one position feels, acts, or is the same.-Terrain actually plays a role in the game's combat.-Buildings actually have a wide degree of rotation (For the most part).Cons:-The game's flidity can be hindered by unexpected obstacles (UI, terrain, etc.).-While the art is incredibly unique, I do understand that it is a bit dated, namely how units and structures act.-Having 2 resources also means having more to protect in specific locations.-Asymmetry can lead to many problems on some of the maps, such as spawns.-Terrain is nice, but the tiniest of bumps can make a well planned base fall apart (So be very careful and wary)-Yes buildings have a surprising amount of rotation, however construction buildings can only be placed one way with minor rotation when placed.The game also came with a map editor and a ridiculous player system, both of which were not great.Building maps was a chore, and had many placement issues.The player count required 4 extra copies if you wanted to take advantage of all 8 player slots.TA Kingdoms improved on both of those features, but was unfortunately the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child, to many people, of the franchise.Although I quite liked Kingdoms, I just feel like it had too many units, and could have been better.Overall I give Total Annihilation a 10/10.Not even the flaws can keep me from loving this Masterpiece of "Ahead of its time" technology.

												TLDR; This is the game that inspired tons of RTS games as well as people. BUYITRIGHTNOWGOI write this review holding my original copy of Total Annihilation in hand. But I'll just set it down, so I can type better. This game is what many other games have tried to emulate, but have failed in some aspect (looking mainly at YOU, Planetary Annihilation). It really should be able to please just about any RTS fan. Want a quick, in your face battle? You got it. Want a long war of attrition? Done (Play Seven Islands for an epic air/sea/nuke battle royale). The campaign is pretty solid too, from what I remember. The music is what I remembered the most, I think. It was just so epic, and fit the game so perfectly. And, for a game that's pushing 20 years old, it still has a charming look to it, not too far off from some indie games released much later. Sometimes pathing can be a bit annoying, but when your units get stuck, just blast them with your Commander's D-gun, for instant gratification.I think really the only negative thing I can say, is that this version includes all the expansion(s). I felt the base game is awesome without the new units and such. Also, I can't help but notice that the AI had to have been tweaked in some ways. It's much more predictable with the xpacs, and dumbed down. It is nice they included the map editor though, sometimes it feels that the provided maps can get stale. That might also be from playing every map many, many times.Cavedog was a pretty legit developer that just unfortunately got overwhelmed by a small market at that time period. I loved their other release, TA: Kingdoms as well. I've sunk tons and tons of hours into both TA series. And Boneyards (their inhouse online service) was so ahead of its time, as far as matchmaking, community, patch releases, and content updates on the reg, it's a shame nothing else has really come along, at least for me, that made the same impression.Pro Tip(s): You want more than 4 players/AI in a skirmish? After hitting the 'single' button, press * and the corresponding roman numeral to the amount of players you want. Example: *X would bump the limit to 10. Reap benefits and/or get rekt.You want to play any campaign mission, any way? From the main menu, click 'Single' then type, drdeath    All one word, no spaces, lowercase. A bone will appear in the gap on the right menu, that once clicked, a campaign master menu opens up, from which you can select any assortment of mission you'd like.

												I'm a pretty crappy writer so I apologize in advance.Total Annihilation is an incredibly unique and intense RTS that was light-years ahead of its time and still is today. I still strongly prefer the original over the more spiritual-successor, Planetary Annihilation.Total Annihilation features so many small features that just make it amazing, the battles can be huge and intense with massive amounts of units having a huge Warhammer 40k esque fight all on one screen, or the games can be slow and brilliantly thought out. This is a strategy game where you can win purely by 'defensive' play at times, something I find to be rather unique among a lot of strategy games that even today have rather narrow methods to win, usually by just having the larger and better offensive force, but not always in Total Annihilation. A feature that makes Total Annihilation so unique is the true emphasis on a defensive playstyle, if you so desire. There are an impressive amount of options for defensive, slow play styles and faster, more offensive playstyles alike. You can choose to hunker down and improve your economy while building a large amount of turrets and upgrading to better ones over the course of the game, some are even capable of bombarding your opponent from the entire maps length, assuming you reach the demanding level of tech and economy required for them. Even tactical nukes can be constructed and launched over a map away if the game length and level of sustainable economy is reached. This allows for a lot of options for a lot of different types of players. There is also no real super demanding macro-memory required à la StarCraft II, making the game just a bit more accessable to newer players, especially in more team oriented game modes.The game also features incredible physics for it's more 2.5 dimensional, isometric strategy experience. One of my favourite things about this game is seeing things like unit inaccuracy, especially when on the move or on unstable ground or even when taking pot-shots at something through the fog-of-war. Units will have better vision when on the high ground and worse vision when in a trench, making a lot of areas on maps incredibly strategic locations. There's even bullet physics, units will often adjust their aim higher or lower depending on the target, and when the steel corpses begin to litter the battlefield they will often block incoming rounds harmlessly while your units continue to trudge past the enemy fire. There's a gritty feeling seeing all your units charge an enemy fortified position only to begin seeing the missiles and rounds begin to rain down upon them and seeing a huge chunk of your force get obliterated by a large round, shaking the screen and sending chunks of steel flying in every direction, the steel "gibs" even damaging nearby units who get hit by them.The game also features an amazing orchestral 'dynamic' music score written and composed by the one and only Jeremy Soule. The music really compliments an already fantastic game nicely, changing to a more brooding tone as you build up your base and switching to a more heart-pounding score as enemy fighters engage your army. It's an incredible soundtrack that you may even consider finding for your own music player. The sound design alone in this game is also very unique and give it a great distinct and 'mechanical' feel.If there was one strategy that I think is criminally unknown to most people, this would have to be it. It's made an amazingly tight-knit community that continue to play the original and have a huge modding scene. (Seriously, try the Total Annihilation Escalation mod, it's just insanely good.) Some even going as far as recreating the Total Annihilation experience in full 3D via an open source engine called Spring, try Spring Total Annihilation out sometime, it has a great community still supporting it to this day.Overall it's my favourite RTS game of all time, and I'm not even a huge RTS fan. It's incredibly exciting just to watch with an amazing soundtrack and huge, epic battles.10/10, would D-Gun again.

												One of the best games of my high school years. I have played this game so much, I don't think any other game can compare. The modding community at the time was crazy, tons of new options to add in. You can still find mods to this day. The first one was great but the expansions added so much more to the game. For its time this game was the Farcry of RTS, graphics were amazing, maps were never ending, and battles were not capped to 200 units per player. Game defaults to 1000 units, however patchs are available, or a simple edit of the config file to allow as many as you desire.When cavedog first offered their gaming service to connect players it was all I ever did. Just some helpful hints to play the game, starting with before you actually play It doesn't appear narration is available in the game, sad face. Maybe it is just mine. Secondly change left click to right click in the menus if your used to other RTS. Game sound starts at mono and can be changes to 3D (Stereo). Options accessed only once you select single or multiple player. Options in game can be selected by pressing tab. Game I believe is auto paused on start for all maps. Resolution support works for 1080p but must be selected, most games at this time barely supported 1280x1028.  While playing: Speed can be adjusted during single and multiple player via the + or - buttons.  Multiple buildings can be queued together using shift. Resource sharing is possible with allies at set increments so you never have to constantly send resources. Building units also has an infinite queue. Holding shift increments 5. Left click to add units, right click to remove. Your commander has a gun called the D-Gun hot key is D, this is a huge blast that can one shot everything but a commander and expieremental units not in the original (later expansions). If your commander dies in campaign it is the end of the match, multiplayer depending on settings. Your commander blows up like a big nuke. Planes build the slowest, then Kbots, then vechicles. Forgot hover vechicles, but they are in an expansion as well. Each one has different perks, and should be used together to cordinate strikes. However planes usually over power all else, as they are fast, hard to hit, and cheap to build.

IntroductionOne of the seminal 3D games of the RTS genre, this game was far ahead of its time when released. Total Annihilation still remains peerless in how well rounded it is, from both sequels and rivals.MechanicsThe simplicity of the mechanics is the game's strongest point. All aspects of the game are easy to understand and intuitive. From a clean UI, to satisfying movement and speed of vehicles, the game just feels right. Once you've completed the campaign, skirmishes will entertain for a long time.GraphicsThe visuals still hold up, with solidly modeled machines, angling to accommodate the contours of the landscape - an original feature at release, it still looks convincing to this day. A very complete selection of environment types to choose from, offering varied experiences.SoundThe music of the game is excellent. Sometimes pensively tense, at other times sorrowful, and occasionally stirring with strident pride - but always memorable.ConclusionPerhaps one of the most wholesome RTS games of all time, and certainly one of the most technologically innovative of its time. Own a piece of PC gaming history.

												This is a great game, very easy to learn and with enough unit choices that it allows a number of playing styles.  As an example, I tend to play with multiple static long range artillery bases, using anti-air defence to protect the assets and scout aircraft to look for things to crush.  However, if you like tanks (you do right?) then you can build a sexy amount of them and ram them down the enemies throat. There are land, sea, sub-sea and air units, as well as structures that provide various functions. In a game like this, you want to be using up 100% of your produced resourses 24/7, pumping out as many units as you possibly can. If you go over, you run your storage dry and production gets slower. If you dont use 100% you end up wasting excess when your storage is full. Default maps are very bland for me, i usually just to randomly pick one and go with it. And if you play against the AI, even on the hardest difficulty you are going to destroy them easily in a 1v1, once you know the base of the game.

												Unless nostalgia rules your life, I'd have to say pass on this game (unless it's on sale or free). It's not that it's a bad game per se; rather, it hasn't held up over time.The main things about Total Annihilation (specifically, the Steam version) that make me not want to recommend the game are listed below:  • The available screen size is very limited compared to modern successors. It makes finding enemy units firing from far off screen very difficult, and base management as well.  • The command interface is split across several pages, and is non-intuitive compared to modern games but also compared to some of its contemporaries (Age of Empires, Warcraft 2, Command & Conquer: Red Alert, etc.)  • The unit movement and structure placement is very finicky -- once again, this is based upon my comparisons to modern RTS games of its kind, but watching a robot spend several (5+) seconds walking into a wall isn't as entertaining as you might think.  • Also, I felt that several of the campaign missions are very unbalanced, but your opinion may differ on this point.Therefore, it was a good game during its heyday when it was fresh and introduced new and novel features to RTS games, but I can't recommend it now.(P.S. At one point, I did alt+tab out of the game, and added an exception, when prompted, to the Windows Firewall to allow this game to communicate. We were able to see each other's game on the list of games, but when either of us attempted to join the other's hosted game, the interface would lock up and hang indefinitely.My review of not recommending this game is solely based on the game's current state. The networking code is obviously dated and doesn't "work out of the box," requiring tweaking and/or third-party extensions to make it work. This is not what I had in mind when I paid $5 for the Steam version of this game.As far as the game itself, my friend and I had a lot of fun playing this game a decade ago when it worked. 												Initially I thought this was a great game until I discovered one particular bu****** mechanic. Since WHEN does a building count as a unit? In pretty much every RTS ever made, a unit is MOBILE, a character or vehicle with combat, constructive, or special abilities. Buildings are STATIONARY. They typically do nothing to defend your base and are used for production purposes. So, let's say you're expanding your base, fighting tooth and claw for metal, building solar complexes and also building DEFENSES to PROTECT what you've had to fight hard for. Laser towers on resource spots, production buildings abroad so you can deploy forces from key locations. Well guess what? This whole time you've been expanding your base, you have been taking space from your COMBAT UNITS. There is a UNIT CAP. So now, if you do have an expanded base, there's a good chance the enemy has a larger fighting force than you and regardless of whether you attack or wait to be attacked, you'll take heavy casualties and the enemy will sense this and just overwhelm you with a larger army. Oh and the game DOESN'T tell you how close you're getting to the unit cap. So you basically have to finely tune the production of everything or else you might waste an hour and a half because your fighting units are crippled by the unit cap. This is the issue I've found in campaign and it's kind of horse s***.In closing, why does a game called TOTAL ANNIHILATION, which is about the mass production of combat robots between two factions who have been hating each other for 400 years have this cap? It's like putting a diaper on a grizzly bear. Wherever we look, sentient robots are a HUGE problem. Terminator: the whole damn planet has been overrun with machines. Mass Effect: THE WHOLE F****** UNIVERSE is about to be destroyed by machines. Robots bring two things when they attack, firepower and numbers. In a game like Age of Empires it makes sense. Want to train more troops and villagers? You need more houses/castles for your people to shelter in. Robots don't give a f*** about rest and typically don't care about how much space is left on the planet, they just want to kill stuff!

												Certainly not a perfect version. It still has issues of disappearing status bar at the bottom of the screen if you actually run AT your resolution (1920x1080 for example), you gotta run at something like 1680x900 in order to actually see the entire UI on screen, which is ridiculous.And it really is a must, because you NEED that status bar to see build rates, energy and metal rates, etc for selected or hovered-over items and factories.The great thing however is that this IS the best working version so far. You dont have to edit .ini files or use third party apps to get it running properly in fullscreen without glitches, apart from the above mentioned. For that alone it is worth a rebuy (because we cant really blame the original devs for not considering Windows 8 / 10 compatability, now can we?) :)That said, I highly recommend people to immediately get some of the convenience mods / balance patches out there.In some ways they are almost required to enjoy the game in a modern RTS mindset.Such as being able to select groups with just pressing 1, instead of pressing Alt+1 which was ridiculous at that time, and is still highly user-unfriendly today.Or being able to hold and drag buildings when holding shift. Makes building walls feasible, which it wasnt in vanilla TA placing one at a time, click click click click.A great masterpiece of a game that DOES show its age due to some weird control schemes they opted for in the old days.But with mods to modernize and "logicalize" the controls, it still holds up today, despite the awful pathfinding.The pure atmosphere and "feel" of the game is still un-rivaled. No other RTS "feels" like TA.Perhaps it is the music, perhaps it is the graphics, perhaps it is the clunky slow controls.No matter what it is, it is greater than the sum of its part. A robbery at this price, must-buy.

												This game... This is a game I like to remember as being one of the best RTS games ever. Being released in the late 90s it came out amongst other great RTS games like, Starcraft, Warcraft 2, Red Alert, Command and Conquer and Age of Empires. Back then the RTS competition was a tough one to beat and Total Annihilation proved it could be on top with the rest of them. Its gameplay is smooth, it works and its easy to learn.The resources in this game are Energy and Metal, and the resource gathering is different but works in the case of Income and Loss. Your income will be determined by things such as how many solar collectors you have for energy, and how many metal deposits you are collecting from. You always want to aim for your income to higher than your loss at all times even when you're building, this way you can almost avoid any loss in resources all together. The best way to explain this is like this; Max Metal and Energy at the start is 1000 in stores, A barracks could cost 500 metal and 2350 energy, the game will decide how much you will lose per second that its being built, so youre income of metal might be 5.4, and energy is 111 you're loss might then be 6.2 and 120 so you will start to lose these resources over time and could run out of energy before its finished you avoid this by building more energy collectors to make the income of energy much higher and then not run out of energy in the middle of building.Most of the gameplay exists around your one main builder unit, The Commander, this guy builds all your buildings and gathers temporary resources (of which btw is pretty much everything, you can gather trees and folliage for energy. Rocks and whats left of units are gathered as metal.). That being said however, once your base is built up and your income of resources is good, is where you start to build your massive robotic army of your infantry, vehicles and aircraft. There is no population cap so you build as much as you like. Through reading everything that is said about the units and buildings you'll be able to find a good mix of what you need nice and easy. Pros: -Quick Gameplay- Gameplay makes sense and works- Robot Armies- A different type of resource collecting not seen often- A long story driven campaign- Pretty much everything explodesCons: - its from the 90s so graphics will be out dated- Resources might get annoying to keep at a steady rate

												Total Annihilation is one of the true classics of the RTS genre, and IMHO, a must-own for any strategy fan. While parts of it can feel dated today, the basic mechanics, gameplay, and the epic score still hold their own nearly 20 years later. I first bought this game barely a month after release, back in the beforetime of 1997, and it's been perpetually on my favorite games of all time list since then. At a time when Starcraft was dominating the RTS market, Total Annihilation was providing an alternative to the small scale clickfest style of gameplay that Starcraft ushered in, offering large maps, epic battles, physics-based combat, and some truly memorable moments. Why throw a dozen marines at something when you can command a hundred-plus giant robots and tanks to obliterate everything in their path?The game definitely had and still has its faults - players unfamiliar with the game are going to be confused by the relative sameness of some of the units, and the sheer numbers of them available to build. It also featured an active use economy; the first of its kind that I'm aware of - I personally love it, but it does entail quite a learning curve from the classic Dune II/Age of Empires "spend it when you build it" model. Some of the larger maps are also not for the faint of heart - while eventually outdone by Supreme Commander, the larger TA maps can take literally hours of multiplayer slug-matches to end a game, particularly once you bump up the unit count to something a modern computer can sink its teeth into.In the end though, it's said that an amateur thinks in terms of strategy, while a professional thinks in terms of logistics - and that's absolutely the case here, where you can spend yourself into inaction, or use the shattered remains of your opponents' armies to fuel your own war machine.

												Total Annihilation is a ridiculously fun and addictive RTS game that was developed in 1997 by a little company called Cavedog. For an almost 20-year-old game, it's amazing how fun this game is to still play. The user interface is very user-friendly, and the game itself is simple to learn. Despite the ease of being able to get into the game and just start playing, there is a wide variety of units that allow an incredible level of complex creativity in terms of strategy. Total Annihilation is like eating candy without the calories: it gives you a cool robot army, huge explosions, and probably one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard composed for a game.Total Annihilation is also very mod-friendly and customizable. Despite being a great game, there are some pitfalls: Getting a multiplayer game can be tricky if you have no idea what you're doing. You will need to connect to the ip address of the host, which most modern games do for you automatically. Additionally, there is a unit cap of 250 (which includes buildings) that you *can* increase, but you have to manually edit the totala.ini file. This can be a pain in the butt for the computer-challenged, but isn't difficult to actually do. The main complaint I hear about this game is the pathfinding. And I agree. Sometimes your units will do what seem to be nonsensical things, like trying to drive up a wall instead of going around it. Very large armies also have difficulty moving around, and the units tend to get stuck on each other. Naval units are the best example of this, where they will grind against each other trying to find their way to a destination. There ARE pathfinding patches out there that will significantly help with these difficulties, though.Overall, this is a great game. I highly recommend it for pretty much anyone ever.
